sn1.23:1.1: The “tangle” (jaṭā) is the tangled hair or dreadlocks of the Brahmanical jaṭila ascetics, as is made clear in SN 7.6 where a dreadlocked brahmin opens with the same verse. The claim is that jaṭila ascetics are as tangled in their minds by craving as they are in their hair.
sn1.23:2.1: In a bold literary conceit, the vast compendium of the Visuddhimagga positions itself as an explanation of this single verse.
sn1.23:2.2: Here citta (“mind”) stands for samādhi or jhāna, which is normally the case in the Suttas on the path (eg. cittasampadā = samādhisampadā, cittabhāvanā = samādhibhāvanā, adhicitta = samādhi, etc.)
sn1.23:3.1: The previous verse dealt with the one who is practicing; this verse with the perfected one; and the final verse with final extinguishment.
